content:
Actually a similar clash exists already:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/16990aec361ade0d8e3f8b1967d9f84bc70

Anyway, I've added a pair of test and validator because the existing ones don't cover the situation where
* the string ends in ")",
* the number of "(" is equal to the number of ")",
* and yet the string is invalid because a ")" appears before the corresponding "(".

Then I've also added 4 more pairs of tests and validators to balance the output of True and False in the validators. (After the edit stated above, there were only 1 False and 5 True for the validators.)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Seems cool, took me a couple of minutes to come up with the solution, however, definitely seems doable in reverse mode. Additionally, it's different than normal puzzles as it's a mixture of [], {}, and (). However, this is () alone. Definitely wanna see more of these types of clashes in the future!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really interesting, this is the kind of puzzle I would like to see more often in CoC

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think that it's a very good idea with reverse mode. The algorithm is not very difficult but needs reflexion to be created what is a good thing. I really like the fact that many solutions can be found to the same problem and make this one very interesting.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

- I understand the game mode is reverse so either goal has to be  removed or should be more explicit. What is a valid expression ?
- May it be could considered expression like
((c==1) && (b==2)) as a valid expression ?
- Precise the type of the output (boolean or string ?)

I like the idea of this in reverse. however, I would like to see the following changes before approving: 

- Even though the only game mode is reverse, it would be useful to have a statement, goal, input and output, in order to have a good view on the problem when reviewing both the solution and the tests/validators. 
- None of the tests nor validators contain a case ")(". This should (I believe) be added to match your code, as currently simply checking that the number of each type of parenthesis is equal is enough to solve it...  
- What should be the output in case there is an other character than ")" or "("? 
- I feel like this could be fun in shortest as well. 

Personnal code with the current tests and validators (so not taking order of parenthesis into account), in Python: 

x=lambda y:(y=="(")-.5
print(sum(map(x,input()))==0)

Thans for your advice! I modified it, you should think about the order.
So, It's not that simple. ^_^
I made a simple change at output.

Still almost that simple (Code Golf style - with the current tests and validators) ^^: 

v=0
for t in input():v+=(t=="(")-.5+(v<0)*-9
print(v==0)

However, it might be interesting to add other characters into the mix, maybe by saying that 
(a+b)*(c)-d is valid, and (if you want to complicate it) (a+b)*(c-d=e) isn't...

Ok, you can really write the clean code. However, it is complicate  enough for the clash, i think.

But, we can make it more easy using "eval", ha-ha，like:

ok = True
try: eval(input())
except SyntaxError: ok = False
except: pass
print(ok)

maybe it can also pass your more complicated case.

To be honest, I tried to do it in a compact way rather than clean ^^ 

Mainly because clean would make you obviously follow the rules, and any CoCer will try to think it as short as possible to write it down fully asap...
